node.text:
The covid-19 pandemic has reinforced humanity’s dependence on modern tech, but the same tools that enable remote working are also being used to spread disinformation and perpetuate cybercrime. Ambivalence towards technology is nothing new.

Cover image credit: Scott Strazzante/The San Francisco Chronicle via Getty Images

node.text:
More than 50 countries around the world have pledged to become net zero. But what does net zero actually mean—and is it achievable?

Cover image credit: Brandon Thibodeaux/ The New York Times / Redux / eyevine

node.text:
In the past couple of weeks South Africa has witnessed the worst violence since the end of apartheid in 1994. Our correspondent in Johannesburg explains what he has seen on the streets and why the country is in crisis. 

Cover credit: Getty Images

node.title: South Africa: what's behind the riots?

node.text:
In America, the intelligence services deem far-right extremism a greater domestic threat than Islamist terrorism. The pandemic has exacerbated the spread of white supremacism and neo-Nazism.

Cover image credit: Michael Nigro/Pacific Press/LightRocket via Getty Images

node.title: Fortnite to far right: the rise of digital extremism

node.text:
Across much of the world, covid-19 restrictions are starting to ease. The Economist has crunched the data to calculate how close countries are to pre-pandemic levels of normality—but will life ever be the same again? 

Click on the link in our bio to visit our website and explore our interactive normalcy tracker. It covers 50 countries which account for 76% of the world’s population and 90% of its GDP.

Cover image credit: Lluis Gene/AFP via Getty Images

node.title: Covid-19: why your life will never be the same again

node.text:
The world’s animals and wildlife are going extinct at a greater rate than at any time in human history. Can technology help turn the tide?

Cover image credit: Yashpal Rathore/Nature Picture Library

node.title: Mass extinction: what can stop it?

Credit: Alamy

node.text:
In America, black people are almost twice more likely to die from covid-19 as white people. Our journalists explain how the pandemic has illuminated systemic racism in America. 

Cover image credit: Getty Images

node.title: How covid-19 exposes systemic racism in America

node.text:
It was once hoped that the internet would be a force for openness and freedom. It was not to be. ⁠
⁠
Bad information often drove out good. Authoritarian states co-opted the technologies that were supposed to loosen their grip. Information was wielded as a weapon of war. ⁠
⁠
Amid this disappointment one development offers cause for fresh hope: the emerging era of open-source intelligence. ⁠
⁠
The emancipation of information promises to have profound effects—and can humble some of the world's most powerful countries. ⁠
⁠
To read how open-source intelligence will make the world less mysterious and a little less dangerous, click on the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
Cover: @markalexlong

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 07, 2021. May be a cartoon of 2 people and text that says 'WHY SATAN SHOULD CHAIR YOUR MEETINGS'.

node.text:
Which character from literature would you be in an office meeting? ⁠
⁠
On any given weekday some 50m meetings are held in American workplaces alone. The average executive now spends 23 hours in them each week, a figure that has more than doubled since the 1960s. ⁠
⁠
People have been gathering to discuss decisions since Adam and Eve huddled over the forbidden fruit. The Western canon is ripe with unharvested wisdom on how to make meetings more productive. ⁠
⁠
Word of advice from @1843mag, don't be a Ralph or an Agamemnon. Play the devil instead. Tap the link in our bio to read a literature lover’s guide to office politics.⁠
⁠
Illustration: Pierlugi Longo

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 07, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Business The tycoon who controls ports, power stations, solar farms and airports'.

node.text:
Long before the hoodie was invented, pioneers of business preferred to call themselves self-made men rather than entrepreneurs.⁠
⁠
Gautam Adani is one of those people.⁠
⁠
He started his career haggling for diamonds, and now controls more ports, power stations, solar farms and airports than almost any other private tycoon.⁠
⁠
Mr Adani is a champion of Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s drive for self-reliance, he courts environmental, social and governance funds from around the world.⁠
⁠
But Adani Group’s hunger for capital creates a conundrum as it increasingly peddles its clean-energy businesses. Tap the link in our bio to find out why. ⁠
⁠
Illustration: @brett.ryder.illustration

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 07, 2021. May be an image of 3 people and people standing.

node.text:
⁠Is Evo Morales staging a comeback in Bolivia?⁠
⁠
In 2019 signs of fraud in an election apparently won by the leftist president, Evo Morales, led to weeks of protests. After the police and army withdrew their support, Mr Morales resigned and fled to Mexico.⁠
⁠
Following Luis Arce’s election, Evo Morales returned to Bolivia late last year, and appears to be keen to get back into politics.⁠
⁠
The opposition argues that the origins of the uprising and the rupture of democracy lay not in 2019 but in 2016, when Evo Morales ignored constitutional term limits.⁠
⁠
But many people no longer care whether what occurred in 2019 was fraud or a coup. To find out why the need for jobs, vaccines and food is a more pressing concern, tap the link in our bio. ⁠
⁠
Credit: Gaston Brito/Getty Images

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 07, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, standing, horse and outdoors.

node.text:
America’s state fairs grew from a 19th-century tradition of agricultural shows, which had the dual aim of binding communities and educating farmers about technology.⁠
⁠
And even as their budgets have ballooned, most retain that spirit. ⁠
⁠
But the flipside of small-town America’s nostalgia is mistrust of the future. Perhaps it is time to renew some of their original modernising purpose. ⁠
⁠
Tap the link in our bio to read more on why state fairs reveal the enduring delights of American folk tradition—and the dynamism it has lost. ⁠
⁠
Credit: Alamy

node.text:
⁠Scientists are taking steps now to be prepared for anything that a future pandemic might throw at the world.⁠
⁠
Understanding what a virus might look like in years to come gives those designing vaccines and therapies a leg up, enabling them to prime more immune systems sooner, so that fewer people die.⁠
⁠
One example: protecting people by programming their immune systems against future pathogens, not just those already circulating, would be a fundamental shift in the meaning, purpose and ethics of inoculation.⁠
⁠
Click the link in our bio to learn how every increase in the speed of vaccine development means thousands of saved lives.⁠
⁠
Illustration: @ryanxchapman

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 07, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, child, outdoors and text that says 'International The 70-year-old global convention on refugees is needed more than ever'.

node.text:
Last year, despite the pandemic’s brake on migration, 1.4m people sought protection outside their home countries; nearly 10m were forcibly displaced within them. ⁠
⁠
That brought the total number of forcibly displaced people to 82.4m, the highest on record. About 30m are refugees or asylum-seekers—people asking for refugee status.⁠
⁠
These numbers are bound to grow, and further strain adherence to the refugee convention, which has just turned 70.⁠
⁠
Keen as rich countries are on the idea that refugees should stay as close to home as possible, they do relatively little to help the countries that host them. ⁠
⁠
And many Western countries continue to duck their obligations to the migrants who do manage to reach their borders.⁠ To read how governments can do more to make the treaty work, click on the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
Credit: Paul Ratje/AFP via Getty Images

node.text:
It seems little can be done to change the minds of the 30% of American adults who are yet to have covid vaccines.⁠
⁠
The country has slipped down the global league table for vaccinations, to 28th. ⁠
⁠
America has now given an average of 1.2 doses per person to its population aged 12 and over. But over the past 14 days it has administered on average 2.2 doses per 1,000 people per day, slower than the pace in 112 other countries.⁠
⁠
Click the link in our bio to read how most unvaccinated Americans have been unmoved by the recent wave of hospitalisations.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 07, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Briefing Open-source intelligence challenges state monopolies on information'.

node.text:
Academics, activists and passionate amateurs are making use of intelligence capabilities once reserved for superpowers.⁠
⁠
The techniques of non-state open-source intelligence have been used to identify concentration camps in Xinjiang, the poisoning of a Russian spy and even the launch of a North Korean nuclear missile (pictured). ⁠
⁠
The intelligence world is being democratised. This is challenging governments, reshaping diplomacy and chipping away at the very idea of secrecy.⁠
⁠
What techniques are being used? To read how the capabilities of open-source intelligence groups have grown, and what they have found, click on the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
Credit: Planet Labs Inc.

node.text:
Desperate for a lie-in but the neighbours keep waking you up? This fox can relate. ⁠
⁠
In this clip, a black-crested titmouse steals fur from a sleeping fox. ⁠
⁠
Birds often use mammal hair, fur or wool to insulate their nests, especially to improve the survival chances of their young in colder climates. How they got hold of the hair had, until now, been unknown. ⁠
⁠
The common assumption was that they gathered any hair they found lying around in their local environment. A new study, however, has found that some birds are far braver—they pluck hair directly from live mammals. ⁠
⁠
The researchers, led by Mark Hauber, a behavioural ecologist at the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign, have coined a new name for this behaviour: “kleptotrichy”—from the Greek “klepto-” (to steal) and “trich-” (hair). ⁠
⁠
It takes its inspiration from “kleptoptily”, a word scientists have used for several years to describe the theft of feathers.⁠
⁠
If you're interested in science stories such as this, head to the link in our bio to sign up for "Simply Science", our free weekly newsletter. ⁠
⁠
Credit: ⁠TexasBackyardWildlife.com⁠

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 06, 2021. May be an image of indoor.

node.text:
⁠Last year Xi Jinping, China’s president, said Xinjiang had scored “unprecedented achievements” in developing its economy and improving people’s lives. The reality is much grimmer.⁠
⁠
Analysis of satellite imagery points to factories being built alongside many of the region’s expanding prisons. Testimonies from inmates suggest that forced labour is common.⁠
⁠
Officials may hope that Xinjiang will follow the model of coastal provinces such as Guangdong and Zhejiang, where the path to prosperity began with factories that made cheap clothes and shoes. ⁠
⁠
But far from laying a foundation for growth, the pursuit of such stability is more likely to end in stagnation. ⁠
⁠
To read why China’s efforts to lift Xinjiang’s economy may instead smother it, tap the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
Credit: Zhang Peng/LightRocket via Getty Images

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 06, 2021. May be a cartoon of text that says 'Finance Finance & economics America's roaring recovery might carry lessons for future recessions Ⅲ 出'.

node.text:
America’s economic recovery has been blistering. It carries lessons for the future. ⁠
⁠
By contrast with past recoveries, this one has been positively blistering, thanks to a burst of deficit spending rivalled only by that during the second world war.⁠
⁠
The pandemic has forced many firms to experiment with new technologies, working patterns and business models. The effect on output per worker in some sectors has been dramatic.⁠
⁠
Whatever the outcome, America’s spending will have purchased a faster recovery. Tap the link in our bio to find out how new information could best ease the pain of a future recession.⁠
⁠
Illustration: @ottographic
